title: How to learn htmlblog
content:
HTML (HyperText Markup Language) Overview

1. Basic Structure of an HTML Document

Every HTML document starts with the declaration <!DOCTYPE html>, followed by the <html> element which contains the <head> and <body> sections:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8" />
    <title>Title of the page</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>Page Heading</h1>
    <p>Some paragraph content.</p>
  </body>
</html>

2. Elements and Tags

HTML elements are represented by tags. For example:

<p>This is a paragraph.</p>
<h1>This is a heading.</h1>

3. Attributes

Attributes provide additional information about elements, like a linkâ€™s destination:

<a href="https://www.example.com">Visit Example</a>

4. Headings

HTML has six levels of headings from <h1> to <h6>:

<h1>Main Heading</h1>
<h2>Subheading</h2>

5. Paragraphs and Text Formatting

Paragraphs are defined with the <p> tag. You can format text using bold, italic, and more:

<p>This is a <strong>bold</strong> paragraph with an <em>italic</em> word.</p>

6. Links and Images

Links are created with the <a> tag, and images with the <img> tag:

<a href="https://www.example.com">Click here</a>
<img src="image.jpg" alt="A beautiful scenery" />

7. Lists

HTML supports ordered and unordered lists:

<ul>
  <li>First item</li>
  <li>Second item</li>
</ul>

8. Tables

Tables are used to organize data in rows and columns:

Header 1 Header 2
Row 1, Cell 1 Row 1, Cell 2
Row 2, Cell 1 Row 2, Cell 2

9. Forms

Forms collect user input:

<form action="/submit" method="post">
  <label for="name">Name:</label>
  <input type="text" id="name" name="name" />
  <button type="submit">Submit</button>
</form>

10. Semantic HTML

Semantic elements like <header> and <section> clearly describe their purpose:

<header>
  <h1>Page Title</h1>
</header>
<section>
  <h2>Section Title</h2>
  <p>Section content goes here.</p>
</section>
